event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item: Replace faulty dimm. Use 'fmadm faulty' to identify the dimm.
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: A fatal error occured while trying to deploy spare memory.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
Title
  Spare memory error


Type
    Fault


Severity
    Major


Description
    A fatal error occured while trying to deploy spare memory.
 

Automated Response
    System panic or reset by BIOS


Impact
    System may panic or be reset by BIOS


Suggested Action for System Administrator
    Replace faulty dimm. Use 'fmadm faulty' to identify the dimm.



Details
Message ID: INTEL-8001-G2 indicates that the %DISTRO% Fault Manager has received
an error report indicating a spare memory error has occurred.



The recommended service actions for this event are as follows:

      Section A -  Identify Faulty Component / FRU
      Section B -  Contact Authorized Service Provider
      Section C -  Clearing Fault after Replacement
  


Section A -  Identify Faulty Component / FRU

   
      LEGEND
      GREEN =  FRU
      BLUE    =  EVENT_ID
      RED      =  SUNW-MSG-ID

     %DISTRO% provides commands that can be used to obtain information about faults present in the system.
     The "fmadm faulty" command is the preferred method by which fault information can be obtained.
     The "fmdump -av" command is an alternative method for obtaining simular fault information.

  •     %DISTRO% nomenclature numbering assignment is zero-based, therefore all numbering begins with the number 0.
  •     The term "chip" is used to describe the physical CPU/Processor.
   
       Note:  The Event-ID  shown in Step A1 and UUID shown in Step A2 are one in the same,
                  as is the MSG-ID shown in Step A1 and SUNW-MSG-ID shown in Step A2.



       Step A1.  How to Identify the faulty memory DIMM using "fmadm faulty".
                
               Example:  Use fmadm (1M) faulty to list the faulty FRU's, unique Event_ID,  and Sun Message_ID.

                     # fmadm faulty
                     -----------------    --------------------------------------------   ------------------   ------------
                     TIME                     EVENT-ID                                                   MSG-ID                SEVERITY
                     -----------------    --------------------------------------------   ------------------   -------------
                     Sep 26 19:00:24   bce027cd-49ba-69d6-99aa-8a98fa2548cd   INTEL-8001-G2  Major
 
                    Fault class : fault.cpu.intel.quickpath.mem_spare

                     Affects: hc:///motherboard=0/chip=1/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/dimm=0
 
                     FRU: hc://:product-id=ASSY,MOTHERBOARD,LYNX_SERVER:chassis-id=0000000000:server-id=wgs40-117:
                     serial= :part=49LF008/motherboard=0/chip=1/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/dimm=0

                     Description : A fatal error occured while trying to deploy spare memory.
               
                     Response : System panic or reset by BIOS
 
                     Impact : System may panic or be reset by BIOS
 
                     Action : Replace faulty dimm. Use 'fmadm faulty' to identify the dimm.


               If your product does not provide the "fmadm faulty" output as shown above, proceed to Step A2.


               The example shown in Step A1;
  • Identifies the physical processor as "chip=1" in the line beginning with FRU.
  • Identifies the faulty memory DIMM as "dimm=0" in the line beginning with FRU.
  • Identifies the location of the physical memory DIMM within the server as; "/motherboard=0/chip=1/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/dimm=0
                          There is typically one motherboard in a server and it is commonly referred to as "motherboard=0".
                          The physical processor, "/chip=1", refers to the second physical processor on the motherboard.
                          The physical DIMM, "dimm-0", refers to the faulty memory DIMM.


                          Recommended service action is to replace the memory DIMM.

                Proceed to Step A3.



       Step A2.  How to Identify the faulty memory DIMM using "fmdump -av".
             
               Example:  Use fmdump (1M) to list the faulty FRU's, unique Event_ID,  and Sun Message_ID.

                     # fmdump  -av
                     TIME                            UUID                                                             SUNW-MSG-ID
                     Sep 26 19:00:24            bce027cd-49ba-69d6-99aa-8a98fa2548cd   INTEL-8001-G2
                           100%  fault.cpu.intel.quickpath.mem_spare
 
                                      Problem in: hc://:product-id=ASSY,MOTHERBOARD,LYNX_SERVER:chassis-id=0000000000:server-id=wgs40-117:
                                      serial= :part=49LF008/motherboard=0/chip=1/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/dimm=0
                                            Affects: hc:///motherboard=0/chip=1/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/dimm=0
                                               FRU: hc://:product-id=ASSY,MOTHERBOARD,LYNX_SERVER:chassis-id=0000000000:server-id=wgs40-117:
                                               serial= :part=49LF008/motherboard=0/chip=1/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/dimm=0
                                          Location: -


               The example shown in Step A2;
  • Identifies the physical processor as "chip=1" in the line beginning with FRU.
  • Identifies the faulty memory DIMM as "dimm=0" in the line beginning with FRU.
  • Identifies the location of the physical memory DIMM within the server as; "/motherboard=0/chip=1/memory-controller=0/dram-channel=0/dimm=0
                There is typically one motherboard in a server and it is commonly referred to as "motherboard=0".
                The physical processor, "/chip=1", refers to the second physical processor on the motherboard.
                The physical DIMM, "dimm-0", refers to the faulty memory DIMM.


                 Recommended service action is to replace the memory DIMM.



       Step A3.  How to Identify the "physical" location of the faulty memory DIMM.


               Sun Platforms
               A service label on the top cover and silk screen on the motherboard can assist with identifying the
               physical location of the memory DIMM.  Typically, there is a label in the proximity of the memory DIMM.

               The label nomenclature for a memory DIMM is Dx, whereby 'x' represents the memory DIMM number.

                Sun platforms use zero-based numbering for their labeling scheme, and as such,
                the faulty memory DIMM  identified in our example above (e.g. "dimm=0") would be interpreted as "D0".
                         e.g.
                         dimm=0 maps to the physical location labeled "D0".
                         dimm=1 maps to the physical location labeled "D1".
                         dimm=2 maps to the physical location labeled "D2".
                         dimm=3 maps to the physical location labeled "D3".                       


               Non-Sun Platforms
               A service label on the top cover or silk screen on the motherboard may exist to assist with identifying the
               physical location of the memory DIMM.  Typically, there is a label in the proximity of the memory DIMM..

               The label nomenclature for a memory DIMM can be in the form of:  Dx, DIMMx, etc;
               whereby 'x' represents the processor number.

                If the product uses zero-based numbering for its labeling scheme, as Sun's products do, the faulty
                processor identified in our example (e.g. "dimm=0") would be identified as Dx, DIMMx, etc;
                         e.g.
                         dimm=0 maps to the physical location labeled;  D0, DIMM0, etc;
                         dimm=1 maps to the physical location labeled;  D1, DIMM1, etc;
                         dimm=2 maps to the physical location labeled;  D2, DIMM2, etc;
                         dimm=3 maps to the physical location labeled;  D3, DIMM3, etc;          


               Recommended service action is to replace the memory DIMM.

                The memory DIMM is customer serviceable.



Section B -   Contact Authorized Service Provider


      Please contact your service provider in accordance with the terms and conditions of your service
      agreement to open a service request and to confirm and carry out the required repair actions specified
      by current service policy.

      Your service provider may ask for information displayed using the procedures outlined in Section A.
     
      If the product is covered by a current service agreement with Sun Microsystems, Inc.,
      please refer to the following  instructions for reporting the problem and opening a service request. 


            Auto Service Request (ASR) Activated for the Product

               If ASR has been activated for the product on which this problem was diagnosed, you have,
               or will receive a notification via e-mail confirming a service request has been automatically
               opened along with instructions for viewing the service request.

               All of the fault event telemetry required to open a service request has already been transmitted
               to Sun Services. Unless contacted and instructed otherwise by a Sun Service representative,
               no further actions is required to report this problem to Sun Microsystems.

               The e-mail notification will provide a pointer back to this same article.
              
               If you are reading this article in response to a fault message or SNMP trap generated on the product,
               rather than in response to the ASR notification e-mail above, then you can check on the status of the
               associated service request by logging into the Members Support Center at  http://sun.com/support 

               For more information on Auto Service Request (ASR) and the currently supported products,
               please refer to http://sun.com/service/asr



             Submitting a Service Request via the Members Support Center Portal

                In cases where ASR has not been activated:

                      1.  Login to the Members Support Center at  http://sun.com/support
         
                      2.  Create a Service Request

                      3.  Copy and paste the information displayed using the instructions provided in Section A
                           to identify the faulty FRU(s), into the Service Request notes.




Section C -  Clearing Fault after Replacement

    
      LEGEND
      GREEN =  FRU
      BLUE    =  EVENT_ID
      RED      =  SUNW-MSG-ID

   
     %DISTRO% Command to Clear the Fault

     Once the memory DIMM has been physically replaced and the system is rebooted, a fault management command is
     required to clear the memory DIMM fault from the %DISTRO% fault manager's resource cache to accurately reflect faults
     that are no longer present.

        Invoke the "fmadm repair" command along with the UUID (Universally Unique IDentifier) associated with the faulted processor.
        
           e.g.
           Sep 26 19:00:24            bce027cd-49ba-69d6-99aa-8a98fa2548cd   INTEL-8001-G2


           Note:  The Event-ID  shown in Step A1 and UUID shown in Step A2 are one in the same,
                     as is the MSG-ID shown in Step A1 and SUNW-MSG-ID shown in Step A2.


                       Example:  Use fmadm (1M) repair to clear the fault using the UUID (Universally Unique Identifier).

                           # fmadm repair   bce027cd-49ba-69d6-99aa-8a98fa2548cd
                           fmadm: recorded repair to   bce027cd-49ba-69d6-99aa-8a98fa2548cd
event_registry_properties.name: impact
event_registry_properties.item: System may panic or be reset by BIOS
event_registry_properties.name: response
event_registry_properties.item: System panic or reset by BIOS
event_registry_properties.name: title
